docs.snippet: The Bank of America Corporation said on Wednesday it would sell the last of BankBoston's Latin American assets, those in Chile and Uruguay, for about $650 million in stock in the Brazilian banking giant Itau. After the deal, Bank of America, which...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bank of America Corporation said on Wednesday it would sell the last of BankBoston's Latin American assets, those in Chile and Uruguay, for about $650 million in stock in the Brazilian banking giant Itau.After the deal, Bank of America, which had previously agreed to sell its Brazilian BankBoston operations to Itau through a similar swap, will own 7.4 percent of the Brazilian bank's equity through voting and non-voting shares, it said.Bank of America acquired BankBoston when it bought its parent company, the Fleet Boston Financial Corporation, in 2004 for $48 billion.
docs.abstract: The Bank of America Corporation said on Wednesday it would sell the last of BankBoston's Latin American assets, those in Chile and Uruguay, for about $650 million in stock in the Brazilian banking giant Itau. After the deal, Bank of America, which had previously agreed to sell its Brazilian BankBoston operations to Itau through a [...]

headline.main: Bank of America Selling Units in Chile and Uruguay

docs.snippet: CYCLING    LANDIS ADVISED TO 'LAY LOW' -- Lance Armstrong said he believed Floyd Landis had said too much in public in his attempt to disprove the positive drug test that has put his Tour de France title in jeopardy.     ''In this day and age, you're...
docs.lead_paragraph: CYCLING LANDIS ADVISED TO 'LAY LOW' -- Lance Armstrong said he believed Floyd Landis had said too much in public in his attempt to disprove the positive drug test that has put his Tour de France title in jeopardy. ''In this day and age, you're not going to get a fair shake in the media,'' said Armstrong, who rode his bike for charity yesterday at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. ''And the more you get out there and talk about it, I have to talk about it. The best is just to let the process play out and get out of the media. I would have encouraged him just to lay low.'' Landis, who once competed on Armstrong's team, appeared on ''The Tonight Show'' this week and has given interviews on all four major network morning shows. He has cited a variety of possible reasons for his failed test. COLLEGE FOOTBALL RICE HEADLINES HALL CLASS -- College seems like a blur to Jerry Rice. ''It went by so fast,'' said Rice, who was a receiver at Mississippi Valley State. ''You're so focused. I wish I could go back and do it all over again.'' That was a common feeling among the 20 men enshrined yesterday into the College Football Hall of Fame in South Bend, Ind. Alabama linebacker Cornelius Bennett, Pittsburgh offensive tackle Mark May and Oklahoma running back Joe Washington said they would love to live those days again. Even fullback Roosevelt Leaks, who faced obstacles in becoming the first black all-American football player at Texas, said he would gladly do it again. ''We all travel different roads,'' he said. ''Whether it was a tougher road or not, there are always obstacles on the road. You keep moving forward. The things that deter you, they usually make you better.'' Others inducted into the hall included Southern California tailback Anthony Davis, the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback John Huarte of Notre Dame, Stanford defensive tackle Paul Wiggin and Michigan defensive back Tom Curtis, along with the former Auburn coach Pat Dye and the former West Virginia coach Don Nehlen. HORSE RACING GO DEPUTY WINS AT SARATOGA -- Go Deputy raced three wide on the turn and took the lead to win the $500,000 Sword Dancer Invitational by two lengths over Silver Whistle yesterday at Saratoga Race Course. Winning for the sixth time in 16 career starts, Go Deputy, trained by Todd Pletcher and ridden by Eibar Coa, ran in 2:26.3 on the turf, returning $15.40 for a $2 bet to win. Earlier, War Front won the $200,000 Alfred G. Vanderbilt Breeders Cup Handicap by two and a half lengths. THE TIN MAN WINS MILLION -- The Tin Man broke first from the gate and led the entire way yesterday to win the Arlington Million in Arlington Heights, Ill. The Tin Man, an 8-year-old gelding trained by Richard Mandella and ridden by Victor Espinoza, set the pace early and held off a late charge from Cacique in the stretch to win by a length. BASKETBALL NOWITZKI LEADS GERMANY -- Dirk Nowitzki scored 18 points to lead Germany to a 76-75 victory against Brazil yesterday in a world championships warm-up in Nanjing, China. Cleveland Cavaliers center Anderson Varejao had 25 points for Brazil. Nowitzki, the Dallas Mavericks star, added 16 rebounds. In the earlier game, Tony Parker led France back from a first-half deficit to down European champion Greece, 72-68. Parker, the San Antonio Spurs guard, had 6 points and 3 assists. SKY SETS RECORD WITH LOSS -- The expansion Chicago Sky (4-29) set a W.N.B.A. record with their 29th loss of the season last night, an 84-57 defeat against the host Charlotte Sting. Charlotte had set the mark with a 6-28 record last season. Washington has the worst winning percentage in league history -- 3-27 (.100) in 1998. TRACK AND FIELD RUSSIAN WINS POLE VAULT -- Yelena Isinbayeva of Russia added to her collection of gold medals from major meets yesterday when she won the women's pole vault at the European Championships in Goteborg, Sweden. Isinbayeva, the reigning Olympic and world champion, cleared 15 feet 9 inches for a meet record, then failed in three attempts to beat her world record of 16 feet 5 1/4 inches in rainy conditions. HOCKEY RUSSIAN PROSPECT LEAVES TEAM -- Evgeni Malkin, the star forward and Pittsburgh Penguins draft pick who has said repeatedly he wants to play in the N.H.L., left his Russian pro team during a training camp in Finland yesterday, various Russian news services reported. Malkin was the No. 2 pick in the 2004 draft behind last year's N.H.L. rookie of the year, his fellow Russian Alexander Ovechkin. But he did not play in the N.H.L. last season because the league lacked a transfer agreement with the Russian ice hockey federation. RUGBY CANADA DOMINATES U.S. -- The United States rugby team was routed by Canada, 56-7, yesterday in St. John's, Newfoundland, giving the Canadians a spot in next year's World Cup and sending the Americans to a regional playoff against Uruguay.
docs.abstract: Lance Armstrong says Tour de France winner Floyd Landis should refrain from speaking to media about positive drug tests (S)

docs.snippet: Soldiers loyal to President Joseph Kabila fought for a second day with supporters of his main challenger, Jean-Pierre Bemba. Witnesses said presidential guards, using tanks and heavy machine guns, opened fire around Mr. Bemba’s home in the capital,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Soldiers loyal to President Joseph Kabila fought for a second day with supporters of his main challenger, Jean-Pierre Bemba. Witnesses said presidential guards, using tanks and heavy machine guns, opened fire around Mr. Bemba’s home in the capital, Kinshasa, while he was meeting there with United Nations officials and foreign ambassadors, trapping the envoys inside. About 150 United Nations peacekeepers from Uruguay, using armored vehicles and backed by 130 Spanish legionnaires, secured the street around the residence to allow the diplomats to be escorted out. The clashes began Sunday, as electoral officials announced that Mr. Kabila had failed to win a majority in the election last month and that he would face Mr. Bemba in a runoff in October.

headline.main: Congo: Rival Forces Battle for Second Day
headline.print_headline: CONGO: RIVAL FORCES BATTLE FOR SECOND DAY
